Name: Circular matrix or Coninvolutory matrix
Explanation: A matrix whose inverse is equal to its entrywise complex conjugate : A = A

Name: Congruent matrix
Explanation: Two matrices A and B are congruent if there exists an invertible matrix P such that P A P = B

Name: EP matrix or Range-Hermitian matrix
Explanation: A square matrix that commutes with its Moore-Penrose inverse : AA = A A

Name: Idempotent matrix or Projection Matrix
Explanation: A matrix that has the property A ² = AA = A
Notes: The name projection matrix inspires from the observation of projection of a point multiple times onto a subspace ( plane or a line ) giving the same result as one projection

Name: Invertible matrix
Explanation: A square matrix having a multiplicative inverse , that is , a matrix B such that AB = BA = I
Notes: Invertible matrices form the general linear group

Name: Involutory matrix
Explanation: A square matrix which is its own inverse , i.e. , AA = I
Notes: Signature matrices , Householder Matrices ( Also known as 'reflection matrices ' to reflect a point about a plane or line ) have this property

Name: Nilpotent matrix
Explanation: A square matrix satisfying A = 0 for some positive integer q
Notes: Equivalently , the only eigenvalue of A is 0

Name: Normal matrix
Explanation: A square matrix that commutes with its conjugate transpose : AA = A A
Notes: They are the matrices to which the spectral theorem applies

Name: Orthogonal matrix
Explanation: A matrix whose inverse is equal to its transpose , A = A

Name: Orthonormal matrix
Explanation: A matrix whose columns are orthonormal vectors

Name: Singular matrix
Explanation: A square matrix that is not invertible

Name: Unimodular matrix
Explanation: An invertible matrix with entries in the integers ( integer matrix )

Name: Unipotent matrix
Explanation: A square matrix with all eigenvalues equal to 1
Notes: Equivalently , A − I is nilpotent . See also unipotent group

Name: Unitary matrix
Explanation: A square matrix whose inverse is equal to its conjugate transpose , A = A

Name: Totally unimodular matrix
Explanation: A matrix for which every non-singular square submatrix is unimodular . This has some implications in the linear programming relaxation of an integer program

Name: Weighing matrix
Explanation: A square matrix the entries of which are in { 0 , 1 , −1 } , such that AA = wI for some positive integer w
